p: Linolenic acid, one of the chemical compounds present in A. africana ( Table 2), is also a potent anti-inflammatory agent [ 2, 46]. It downregulates inflammatory iNOS, COX-2, and TNF- α gene expression by blocking NF- κB and the activation of MAPKs in murine macrophage cell lines stimulated by LPS [ 2]. Reifen et al. [ 46] observed that α-linolenic acid effectively inhibited IL-1 β-induced inflammation through downregulation of the levels of proinflammatory genes mRNA, which included COX-2 and IL-8. Thus, the presence of linolenic acid in A. africana potentially improves the plant's anti-inflammatory property.
